characters: HIGH-PITCHED WAIL FROM REAR OF BUS
BUNCHE, JACKIE ROBINSON AND HERBERT HOOVER
ROBINSON WINS NATIONAL LEAGUE BATTING HONORS
THE FIELD OVER RICKEY AND REPORTERS
PLAYERS DENY ANTI-ROBINSON PLOT, SAY ROUGHNESS ACCIDENTAL
BETTERMENT RACE RELATIONS AWARDED TO JACKIE ROBINSON
GENERAL EISENHOWER PRESENTS FREEDOM HOUSE MEDALS TO RALPH
THE FIELD FOCUSED ON PITCHER AND BATTER
JACKIE ROBINSON VOTED MOST VALUABLE PLAYER IN THE NATIONA
GEORGE WASHINGTON CARVER MEMORIAL INSTITUTE GOLD MEDAL FO
PLAYING FIELD THE TWO TEAMS IN POSITION TO ST
NEGRO BREAKS INTO BIG LEAGUE BALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Robinson and the children in the taxi as they look o at the scene. (Stock shots of Pasadena's business section then of the residential area are to be inter-cut.)

dialogues.speaker: TAXICAB
dialogues.text: As children leave school, trooping out noisily and happil Among the children are several Negroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children and the mother gaze intently as they note Ne pupils among the white children. Then they gaze at each o as if it is something hard to believe.

dialogues.speaker: TWO OF THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: As they turn their heads to continue looking at the schoo even though the taxi is now some distance past it.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVING INTO NEGRO DISTRICT
dialogues.text: As CAMERA FOLLOWS TAXI, we see that we are now in a low-p area of homes, stores, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had never seen anything like  the city that was to be their new  home. They looked and wondered and  the mother told herself that sooner  or later they would be well, if  humbly, settled there... And -- in  time -- they were... and very  humbly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As narration fades, we

dialogues.speaker: STREET SCENE LONG
dialogues.text: A nine year old colored boy is running towards the Robins home in high excitement. He is carrying a fielder's glove which he has to glance every other second though he is in full flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking through the  following scenes as  well) This isn't Jackie -- but when he was  nine, and the family couldn't afford  to get him a baseball glove, this is  how his mother helped him make a  necessary adjustment to life. Jackie  had found an old, dilapidated glove...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid leaps up the stairs and into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid slides into the kitchen, holding the glove out to Mrs. Robinson who is turning around from the gas range, a talks to her eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the glove, examines it, and has to smile. It is badly frayed, the side stitching burst in a number of pla and padding extruding. Nevertheless, she nods and turns  away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Robinson taking a sewing kit out of a drawer, the ki hopping around just in back of her and getting his head i her way. She goes to table, sits down, and commences thre a needle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to take the first stitch. He asks her somethin anxiously. She nods reassuringly and his face lights up w a heart-wide grin.

dialogues.speaker: STREET SCENE
dialogues.text: The same boy stands at a street corner, a bunch of newspa at his feet, a dozen or so more under his arm, selling pa both to car patrons and to pedestrians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between work and school Jackie, like  this boy, didn't have all the time  in the world to play...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy turns his back to camera as he sells a newspaper we see the glove sticking partially out of his back pocke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but he always kept his glove  handy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running onto an empty lot where several other boys are pl ball in a make-shift game, is Jackie. One of the boys bat out a fly and Jackie scoots after it.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: (NOTE: The following shots, illustrating narrator's talk, are quick, almost montage views, taken against any studio backgrounds already up and available. They are all angled keep face of boy unrecognizable... and as shots progress gets bigger to indicate his growth.)

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR
dialogues.text: Boy mopping a floor.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: Boy delivering package to woman who opens door.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: Boy piling up scrap lumber in corner of yard.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: Boy pushing hand-truck loaded with sacks.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: Boy driving small delivery truck, stopping and jumping ou with parcel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (against above) All the things that boys find to do  when they have to work through their  schoolhood years, Jackie did...

dialogues.speaker: ATHLETIC FIELD
dialogues.text: Track events in progress. Students and fans watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...yet he managed to make time for  sports as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get a bare flash of a young Negro lad in track suit ta his run and launching into a broad jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This still isn't Jackie, but when he  attended Pasadena Junior College he  led in all sports, broke the National  Junior College running broad jump  record with a leap of 25 feet, six  inches -- a record set a few years  earlier by his own brother, Mack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Football game in progress, thousands of fans watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As signals are called and a runner gets the ball. (From t distance we can't recognize any player or distinguish act numbers on their uniforms.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The player with the ball breaks through the opposing team line and dashes for the sidelines and toward camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this -- IS -- Jackie Robinson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As player nears camera we recognize him as Jackie. Over s is HEARD roar of the crowd. CAMERA HOLDS as Jackie runs i a CLOSE SHOT, then past camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...playing football for the University  of California at Los Angeles where  he had won an athletic scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any shot of a player crossing into end zone for a touchdo as opposing players trail after him... this, apparently,  being the end of Jackie's run.

dialogues.speaker: THE CROWD LONG
dialogues.text: They are cheering.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTBALL EXCERPTS
dialogues.text: These should be actual shots of Jackie in action against  various college teams during his UCLA days. (During these should work in a studio CLOSEUP or two to let us take a g look at the man.) Each of the shots is identified by the  narrator as follows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against Southern California!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against Oregon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against Stanford! Etc.

dialogues.speaker: COLISEUM STANDS MEDIUM
dialogues.text: We see small section of student body watching game. Seate with two white girl companions is an attractive Negro gir (Rae). After joining crowd in a cheer one of the white gi turns to Rae.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sure can run! How does it  feel to see your future husband going  wild down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acting taken aback) Future husband? You're faster than  he is! He hasn't got that far yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving hand derisively) Now don't pretend, Rae! We know. (turning to other  white girl) Don't we, Claire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As other nods --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't pretend, Rae!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae laughs but is a little embarrassed at being kidded ab it. The white girl sees this and pats Rae's face, as you  will to a child you are fond of, to indicate she meant no harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another quick shot of action on the field, with crowd roa as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our shot takes in the tailgate of a furniture truck backe close to a warehouse-like entrance or loading platform. A tablet on wall of warehouse reading EMPIRE STORAGE COMPAN helps identify scene. A Negro of about fifty, strongly bu stands on truck tailgate waiting. Jackie, head hidden und huge club chair which he is carrying, walks into scene fr warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't all touchdowns and cheers,  however. There was also work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie swings chair to truck where older man grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wiping perspiration) That's the last one, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake settles chair down, leans against it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you play yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) Yeah? Like the game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (judiciously) It was good. You was good. But what's  the use if you got to do this kind  of work? I didn't have to go to no  college to get this job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, after pause) You see, Jake, you're smarter than I  am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake studies Jackie a moment, and then, with a slow, know smile, lifts chair up and disappears into truck with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General shot campus showing college buildings b.g. and  students either wandering around or lounging on ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there was always studying to be  done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sitting with back propped against tree reading boo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks up as Rae enters scene. He would get up but slips down beside him before he can get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay put. I was held up by Claire  King. She just wanted to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating his book) That's okay. I can use all the time  I can get for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending affront) Oh. Then I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie instantly tosses book over one shoulder and takes of Rae's hands in his so she can't get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending alarm) Your book! What about your book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae has to break down and smile and they are looking at e other as we

dialogues.speaker: FOOTBALL GAME
dialogues.text: Another game with stands loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae and a few people around her.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: A player, indistinguishable, goes down under tacklers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae wincing as voices, o.s., yell:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie's down! Wow! They sure got  him that time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white girl sitting with a boy friend in front of Rae  comments:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) They sure pile on to him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brutally) What do you think? Who wouldn't if  they had a chance to slug...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl pokes him and indicates with her eyes that Rae i seated right behind them. The boy looks back at Rae, then his girl again with a non-committal shrug.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD
dialogues.text: As the players finally unpile. However, the ball-carrier  lies there and two or three of his own teammates rush tow him.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK CUT
dialogues.text: Jackie on ground, ball under him, two or three players tr to help him to his feet. While they do so, the trainer ru into scene to help them. CAMERA HOLDS as the trainer and  another player help Jackie off the field. Over scene come cheer from the crowd, glad that Jackie isn't seriously hu However, he does have a decided limp.

dialogues.speaker: RAE
dialogues.text: She looks greatly relieved.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, TRAINER AND PLAYER
dialogues.text: As they walk toward camera, then past camera, on their wa to dressing room, o.s.

dialogues.speaker: AT ENTRANCE TO DRESSING ROOMS
dialogues.text: As Jackie, the trainer and another player walk into scene and enter the dressing room. All are quiet, and over scen we HEAR roar of the fans again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights are on, there is a doctor's bag on one of the rub- down tables, a dozen or so uniforms tossed on various cha and on the floor near the lockers. The trainer and player help Jackie up onto a table and pull his jersey off. Jack winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking as he works) Hurt much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hip's badly bruised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The player who helped Jackie off the field comes into sho He is angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's wrong with those  guys giving it to Jackie like that.  Just because he's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly) Hold it! I knew before the game they  were out to watch Jackie close. The  trainer on their team told me. But  it was because of his playing ability  and nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get back to the bench. (to Jackie) I wasn't kidding about that either,  Jackie. They had respect for you out  there. Plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie mulls over the trainer's words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dick. It's nice to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Say, Jackie. How's your brother Mack?  I remember him when he went to the  University of Oregon... and when he  ran in the Olympics overseas. One of  the finest athletes I ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after pause) Oh, Mack? He's fine. Fine, thank  you.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT STEPS ROBINSON HOME MEDIUM
dialogues.text: Jackie and Rae are sitting quietly on the steps. Mrs. Rob comes out door just as Jackie slips his body down one ste and lays his head against Rae's shoulder. Mrs. Robinson, has some knitting in her hand, goes to a chair in a dark  corner of the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in some pain, aren't you? I  think football is a wild game. I  don't think I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shifting in discomfort) I don't myself right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's disgusting... young men  battering each other... no better  than just plain old bulls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie gives Rae an amused side glance at this, then shru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it won't last much longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... something. This isn't getting  me anywhere. I mean... this isn't  getting us anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shifts about to look directly at Rae with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's serious!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Oh-h!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes his head around and away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees this byplay and her face softens in a smile. Qui she gathers up her knitting and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT STEPS MEDIUM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Robinson enters house. Jackie hears the door closing and looks around. Then he smiles down at Rae who smiles b in understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you mean, Jackie? About  your going to do something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his face serious) Oh... I mean I'm too big to be just  ornamental... Keeps Mom and Mack  hustling to pay my way... I've got  to start in being real useful...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He is in bed, unable to sleep. He has a school book on a  table beside the bed; a small lamp is burning. He picks u the book and studies it for a few moments, but his heart  isn't in it. A clock on the table shows that it is three  o'clock in the morning. Jackie sighs deeply, then slowly  starts climbing out of bed, still careful of his hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing by the gas range Jackie pours hot coffee into a  vacuum lunch bottle. Two sandwiches are on a piece of pap He corks the bottle and is wrapping up the sandwiches whe we hear Mrs. Robinson's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that? You, Jackie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) You sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Just couldn't sleep. I'm going  out to see Mack. Want to talk to him  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't it wait till morning? It's  three o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. But I won't be long. I know  where to find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fading off) Three o'clock! My! My! What a thing  to do... what a thing to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie walking along Colorado Avenue, or similar business street, deserted and lonely at this hour except for a str cleaner in the distance. Jackie carries the lunch package one hand, much as he would a football. Sandwich and vacuu bottle are wrapped in the same, tight package.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKING
dialogues.text: Jackie approaching street cleaner who, however, does not  hear him because of the noise of his heavy broom and the  fact that parked cars separate the two men.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE AND CAR MEDIUM
dialogues.text: Jackie has reached car. He stops a second and we hear the street cleaner's broom being pushed over the concrete. Ja takes a few more steps, bringing him past the car. He sto and turns in the direction of the street cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowing it will be a  surprise) Hello, Mack.

dialogues.speaker: MACK MEDIUM
dialogues.text: We see that Mack, Jackie's older brother by three years, former University of Oregon track star, is the street cle He is in the loose uniform of the town's sanitation corps and is startled by Jackie's words and appearance, then gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the... what are you doing here  at this hour? Schoolboys should be  in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I couldn't sleep so I fixed  you some lunch. Here...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws the package like a forward pass and Mack, shift broom to crook of his elbow, snags it expertly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping his broom) Man oh man -- I can use some... Hope  you figured I was a bit hungry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is obviously very pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) You bet. Coffee, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating curb) Now you're talking. Let's sit down  and take it easy for a while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack opens the package, takes a sandwich and offers one t Jackie. Jackie shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a bite) Anything bothering you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I want to quit college. Right  after the basketball season... when  my scholarship is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack almost chokes on his first bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pounding Mack's back) Take it easy, boy. I don't want to  lose you now. (getting serious) You know Mom. She sees me as a doctor,  minister or lawyer, perhaps. I'd  like to please her but it just isn't  in me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing his thought) It would mean years more in school --  and the way I feel, I'd rather work  at getting some kind of a sport job --  an assistant coach -- or a trainer --  something like that... But I can't  figure out which to aim at... Coaching  jobs are darn hard to get...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) All I can say, Jackie, is that you  ought to stay in college as long as  you can -- try to graduate -- and  keep at sports as hard as you can.  Something might turn up... and as  far as education goes -- it'll do  you good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, noticing the trash he has been sweeping, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much good -- I'm not saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie nods. Neither of them is at all bitter about it. I is just accepted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure... I know... But I've got to go  to work. I want to marry Rae. School's  one thing -- but you and Mom can't  support me in marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the scene, Mack has continued to eat and now he op the thermos of coffee. Jackie shakes his head that he doe want any and Mack pours himself a cup. As he starts to dr a convertible filled with young people drives in sight, t youngsters singing a football victory song. Jackie and Ma watch it drive by. Banners and streamers hang from the ca all showing UCLA insignia. Mack grins at Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny place for a football hero to  be sitting at this time of night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie grins back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny job you've got for a university  man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kicks at the pile of debris near them. Mack grins back him, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (philosophically) That's the way it is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in silence for a moment and CAMERA PULLS BACK an draws away from them, their figures small against the lon lonely, dark street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A student about to enter calls to another student passing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jerry! Going to watch basketball  practice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passing student shakes his head and points to some bo he is carrying to indicate he has to study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A practice session is on, the players just passing the ba around and shooting baskets. At the sidelines stands an  assistant coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see him run to the basket, get the ball on a pass, and shoot. Catching the ball as it comes through the net he s it far upcourt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) All right, fellows. Let's work out  in teams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players break up into two teams and take position for the start of a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and the player opposing him stand together waiting for the opening whistle to sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That true, Jackie, about your quitting  at the end of the basketball season?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie nods --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even going out for baseball again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you like baseball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't afford to like it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever hear of a Negro in organized  ball?

dialogues.speaker: GAME LONG
dialogues.text: We see a few seconds of game skirmish, and follow Jackie  down the court in a rush towards the basket which he  ultimately shoots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both panting a little now as they line up agains each other again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Well, don't think I'll miss you.  I'll make the first team after you're  gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with friendly dig  into player's ribs) Well, I'll miss you. You kept me  stepping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other player pulls his fist back as if to sock Jackie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out! Kept you stepping! I didn't  have a chance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both grinning as the whistle sounds and they jum into play again.

dialogues.speaker: BASKETBALL GAMES
dialogues.text: We see Jackie in action against other college teams durin the basketball season, and over each separate game appear title identifying the particular rival college involved i the shot. After final shot we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of students on the steps of one of the campus  buildings are reading the college paper which is held by of them.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP MEDIUM
dialogues.text: One of the students is reading aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "UCLA loses four-letter athlete.  Jackie Robinson leaving school."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, that boy's gonna leave a hole  behind him hard to fill. How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the other students rubs forefinger against thumb i the "money sign."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Economics, my boy. A man must live  before he can play. And in order to  live...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes the money sign again as we cut go:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is taking his stuff from his locker and packing it a small bag. The trainer we met in the football sequences and a student are standing by. Jackie is explaining somet to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Coming out of Junior College to  UCLA, the way I did, I only had a  two-year scholarship to fit my  athletic eligibility. Well... the  scholarship is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there any way you can stay on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother is 63 years old. She's  worked as housekeeper, maid, cook,  laundress, janitress and selling  yard goods in a store to keep us  kids going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wanted to do it. She must not  want to see you give up now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she'd work for the next ten  years if I stayed in school...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't take a chance. I can't expect  more future than Mack... and with  all his college he wasn't able to  get anything worth while. That's not  worth ten more years of work for my  mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His packing finished, Jackie shakes hands with both men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luck to you, and I'll take the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) All the luck in the world. You'll  make out all right, Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie exits the trainer turns to the student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow it doesn't make sense. The  only four-letter man we've had at  UCLA in ten years. High basketball  scorer for us in both years he was  here. On top of that he's as fine a  baseball player as I have ever seen...  and it don't mean a thing. He's  walking out of here without anything  ahead of him except a couple of games  of pro-football signed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he can have a career in  professional football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Baseball is his game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tells everyone he doesn't care  about baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a short smile) Yeah... I know. What else is he going  to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of hands counting a roll of paper money, each bill being slapped down on a table. CAMERA MOVES BACK to reveal Jackie standing up and counti the money in front of his mother who is seated at the tab She seems puzzled as she looks at the bills and then up a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Jackie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still counting) Money. Remember, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a warning glance not to joke with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that, Jackie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in mollifying tone) Okay. Okay, Mom. It's an advance  payment for playing professional  football. I'm signed up to play for  Honolulu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tidies up the bills and leaves them in front of her as sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't like for you to play  football. Is that why you quit  college?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mom. I'm going there just to  play a few games. They came to me  when they heard I was going to quit.  We can use the money till I get what  I want. So I took it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honolulu's far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be there and back inside of two  months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is troubled as she looks at the money and then up at  Jackie again. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, maybe, I'll have some  answers to all the letters I've been  writing for a coaching job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she still doesn't reply he smiles and reaches out to pat her folded hands reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be all right, Mom. Just give  me a little time and you'll be proud  of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks directly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was proud of you when you went to  college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely) I know. But... I didn't feel proud  of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Rae are sitting on the front steps, apparently having reached a pause in their conversation which has le them both looking a little troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES IN as we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...May take us a little longer this  way but it means a better start...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she nods mechanically --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it does... uh... (in sudden disgust) Oh... maybe you're right. Maybe I'm  just going around in circles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae turns to him quickly in sudden compunction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to  act so cold to the idea. I'm not  even listening because... because I  just don't want you to go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he tries to talk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I know you have to do something  like this to get a start. I know...  but that doesn't make me like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking her hand) All right. And I am going around in  circles. I don't know how to beat  that. But Rae... there's one thing I  want you to be sure of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she nods --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every circle comes right back to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As her face lights up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all I'm worrying about is getting  around fast enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile at each other and then Rae leans her head back against Jackie's chest. They stay like this, both gazing  off, when she speaks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) I have to take my post-graduate  nursing course in a hospital. I think  I can get in Bellevue in New York.  That's where I'll be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning) But why so far...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to face him) That's where I'll be when you're  ready. It's better that way. Something  for me to do. You're more free...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They study each other's faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A corner of a cabin. Jackie is typing away at a small tab next to a porthole through which we can see a mid-ocean  horizon rising and falling with the roll of the ship. Nex to him is a small pile of letters already written. The di clang of ship's bells is HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see that the letter is printed "S.S. LURLINE - HON BOUND." Under it he has typed the following heading and  salutation: "Mr. W.J. Jeffrey Athletic Director Overton College Overt Calif." And that he is tapping out the first few lines of his let which begins as follows: "Dear Mr. Jeffrey: In application for an athletic coaching, or assistant  coaching, appointment at Overton, I would like to submit following qualifications..."

dialogues.speaker: FOOTBALL SCENES
dialogues.text: Opening with STOCK of Hawaii, then into clips of several  football games, ending with a SHOT of a steamship leaving Hawaii.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He is walking up to the house, carrying a suitcase in eac hand. CAMERA HOLDS as he reaches front door.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He lowers suitcases and knocks at the door as he finds it locked. He waits a moment, gets no answer, then finds his own key and unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie enters, places his bags on the floor and closes the door behind him. He stands there for a moment, then g toward a table where there are several pieces of mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the dozen or so letters and finds that four o them are for him. He sits down, opens and reads them, one one. We do not see the first two which he crumples up and drops into a wastebasket. The third one he re-reads and t about for a moment, then places it to one side. The fourt he reads and crumples again and discards with the others. Then he rises and walks back and forth as he thinks. Afte moment he stands at the living room window and stares out silently.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He stares out of the window, then sees something, turns a heads for the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Robinson is walking up toward the house, carrying tw large sacks of groceries. Jackie hurries to meet her, gre her and taking the packages at the same time, even as the embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happy to see him) I was hoping you'd be here -- your  telegram came just a little while  ago so I went out to get some  things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows that she intended to get some extra-special food for a homecoming dinner. CAMERA PANS them into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and his mother enter and pass through into the kit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they walk through) ...you didn't get hurt, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter kitchen to put down the packages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he enters) Not a scratch. Got a sore arm though --  from writing letters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she follows him  in) Letters? Some letters came for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes back into the living room, heads for the table  where Jackie picked up his mail. As Jackie reenters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put them here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to him, hoping that he will have some good news He smiles at her, then moves over and picks up the letter saved and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING MRS. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: As she reads the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) What's this National Youth  Association...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's something the Government set up  to help underprivileged children ---  they get all sorts of training ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopefully) ...And they want you to be an athletic  instructor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks that way... Anyway, I'm taking  it before they change their minds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Robinson looks at the letter again, then back at Jac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Pennsylvania... (with a smile) You'll be near Rae, anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves to the sofa and sits down as she talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you can be there when she  graduates -- or whatever it is --  from the hospital...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Yeah. (joshing her) So even if we don't have a doctor in  the family, we'll have a registered  nurse, anyway... (reflectively) ...I hope...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not write her and let her know...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Good idea. Soon's I put my stuff  up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, picks up his suitcases and starts through the h door with them and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a room in the nurses' quarters of a large hospita Everything white, clean, uncrowded. Rae, in graduate nurs uniform, is seated at a desk reading a letter. On the des is a picture of Jackie -- in civilian clothes. There is a box of stationery, ink, pen, etc., on the table in additi to several books.

dialogues.speaker: RAE READING LETTER
dialogues.text: She shakes her head, smiling a bit, but with a bit of sad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...I'm enjoying my work with the kids and the Associatio has been fine to me. I'll be leaving it soon, though, as Army has called. But at least, I can stop worrying about future for awhile..."

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Rae folds the letter and smiles in sad contemplation as w hear her thinking voice paraphrase Jackie's last sentence

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can stop worrying now that he's  in the Army...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know that she will really start worrying. She glances the framed photograph of him. As we look at it, Jackie's  clothes change into the uniform of an Army Private.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY POST
dialogues.text: If obtainable we will show quick scenes of Jackie's army  life as he supervises various athletic activities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a picture of Jackie in the uniform of an Army  private. The uniform fades and is replaced by the uniform a first lieutenant. CAMERA PULLS BACK from photograph and we see that Rae is  writing a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...so I will be finished with my course in two weeks and then go back home. When you get your Army discharge I'll waiting for you in California..."

dialogues.speaker: ARMY POST
dialogues.text: This is supposed to be Ft. Breckenridge, Kentucky, althou it can be any large Army installation as long as it remai unidentifiable.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: Marching, training, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MORE SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: Entering and leaving barracks, etc.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He is packing a suitcase and an Army bag. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal another Negro officer with Ja This man sits on a bunk -- both are dressed in their unif Jackie moves to a chest and takes some clothes and stuffs them into the Army bag. Then he takes a photo of Rae off wall and packs that in the suitcase. The last thing he re from the chest is a fielder's baseball glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you going to do with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying glove) I don't know. Don't know if I'll  ever do anything with it again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT JACKIE'S HANDS stuffing glove into his bag.

dialogues.speaker: SAME BAG
dialogues.text: As Jackie's reaches into it and comes out with the glove. There is a burst of laughter as CAMERA PULLS BACK to show that Jackie is home and unpacking his bag in front of Rae Mrs. Robinson and Mack, all three of whom are laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like you. First thing one sees  when you unpack is a baseball glove...  or a pair of spiked shoes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie draws himself up a little stiffish and addresses R in formal tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when have you ever seen me unpack  before, Miss Isum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed in front  of Mrs. Robinson and  Mack) I didn't mean that I had ever seen  you... why, Jackie! What do you... (whirling about) Well, if that's to be your attitude!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flounces from room and Jackie motions to his mother a Mack as he prepares to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I have to effect a...  a... a rapprochement, I think they  call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries after Rae while Mrs. Robinson looks after him then turns to Mack to ask with suspicion edging her voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he mean by that... that  rapproche -- that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking head) Search me. We didn't bother with  that kind of stuff when I went to  college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same scene as Scene 43. Jake is standing on back of truck maneuvering a settee onto its legs when Jackie walks into the scene and smiles up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H'ya, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been out of the Army a long time  now, Jackie. Ain't got yourself a  good coaching job yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grunting) Still writing letters, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But if I don't get an answer  soon I'll be back here looking for  my old job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that don't happen, son. But  if it does... I can sure use you. (changing tone) Why don't you go to them coaching  places in person instead of writing  them letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean why don't I spend fifty  dollars train fare instead of a three  cent stamp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Yeah... I ain't got all the brains  in the world. (laughing louder) I wouldn't even want to prove I got  my share!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two are laughing, with Jake sounding off in wild whoo when Mack's voice is heard, o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Jackie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop laughing and turn around as Mack runs into scen carrying a letter which he hands to Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) It just came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie tears letter open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is reading letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jake) It's from the Kansas City Monarchs.  It can only be one thing... an offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Never heard of the Kansas City  Monarchs? It's a professional baseball  team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought professional teams  don't want us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an all-colored team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks up and Mack can't wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little dazed) A hundred dollars a week... to play  shortstop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake jumps from truck and is so intrigued he takes letter from Jackie to puzzle over it himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) And I didn't even write them. How  did they know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they knew about you from UCLA  and some of the pro games you played  at Brookside. They must have scouted  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing letter back  to Jackie) Here. That's what it says... a hundred  a week. (studying furniture  on truck) Just pushing a little old baseball  around. Maybe there's something to  that college stuff after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a table in a corner at which sit Jackie and Rae, the latter in white uniform of a nurse, and with Coca Cola bo and glasses before them. An air of sadness seems to have  overcome both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Well... you've got to take it. I  don't see what else you can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in same mood) Yeah... and if I can stay with the  Monarchs a couple of years I should  be able to save up a little money. (looking at her) Maybe even enough... (hopefully) Maybe when I know I'm set there,  then...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, but not with any particular enthusiasm. Jackie  notes this and nods slowly in agreement with her reaction

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you. Gee... a couple  more years. Why don't we set a wedding  date for about 1960 and have it over  with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae doesn't think it is funny, even if it wasn't meant to be. She stands up and looks at her wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about 1960, but in five  minutes I'm due back in the ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie gets up and puts some coins on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tomorrow I'm due in Kansas City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand looking at each other, both with blank faces,  unable to fathom either how to solve their problem or wha lies ahead of this new development as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over scenes are SUPERIMPOSED the words: KANSAS CITY.

dialogues.speaker: SIGN
dialogues.text: "MONARCHS vs. CLEVELAND"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o.s., we HEAR crowd noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The playing field. A game is in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fair-sized audience, practically all colored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, in uniform, is sitting in a corner of dugout alon an older man, apparently the manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This being your first game I was  going to hold you out a couple of  innings but maybe you want to take a  lick at bat now? (nodding to batter) Follow Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie starts away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And look! Uh... we give them a show  out there, Jackie. If you make an  out, act mad. If you think you get a  bad call on a ball, talk it up. They  like that here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie considers this, nods, and then walks away quietly. The manager shakes his head as if doubtful that Jackie ca come through on this order.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINES MEDIUM
dialogues.text: Jackie, bat in hand, moves "on deck" and squats, waiting turn.

dialogues.speaker: BATTER
dialogues.text: A Monarch player waggling bat viciously as if daring pitc to throw one in the groove.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE BEHIND BAT
dialogues.text: Holding a "two-three" count up with his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: Gazing contemptuously towards batter, winding up and thro

dialogues.speaker: BATTER
dialogues.text: Striking out with a tremendous swing, he yells in fury an starts pounding the ground with his bat in anger.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINES MEDIUM
dialogues.text: As Jackie moves to plate he passes the retired batter. Th latter is still gesticulating angrily, but as he passes J he winks at him and we know it is all an act for the fans

dialogues.speaker: GRANDSTAND
dialogues.text: As loudspeaker announcement is heard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now batting for Kansas City Monarchs  in place of Rumley -- Jackie Robinson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie takes his stance. The catcher squats and begins ta it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to pitcher) This is a new boy, Bill. Take it  real easy with him. Don't discourage  the new boy. Nice and easy! Nice and  easy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the catcher is talking Jackie turns and nods to him as grateful for the expected gentle treatment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He acts interested in what catcher is telling him, then n as if in gentlemanly agreement with the policy of treatin new man with consideration. He begins his windup slowly b when he finally whips the ball it is with everything he's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball streaks past Jackie's head so closely that he ha to fall to ground to avoid getting beaned. As he gets up, acting fully bewildered, the catcher runs to him and help him dust his clothes, simulating deep concern. Jackie gaz at catcher, and then at pitcher, with great suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDSTAND SMALL SECTION
dialogues.text: The spectators are enjoying this byplay hugely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie waiting and showing determination to hit. He swing and hits... but doesn't run.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDSTAND ROOF LONG
dialogues.text: The ball going high over the stands and onto the roof.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: A new ball is thrown to him. He begins his windup and thr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie swings and misses, so hard that he is carried seve feet from plate and ends up facing stands. He acts angry, pulls his bat back of him with one hand and looks as if h is going to sling it into the seats. For a moment he stands thus, wrestling with himself almos as if trying to control his temper. There is a roar of  excitement from the spectators, and then Jackie lets the down. Lowering his head in deep dejection he starts walki back to the dugout. The crowd's yelling now turns to laug

dialogues.speaker: DUGOUT MEDIUM
dialogues.text: As Jackie steps in to resume his seat next to manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastic) That was great, Jackie! Fine stuff!  They loved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie nods --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, of course, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie looks up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're also supposed to get a hit  once in a while

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He casts an amused look at manager from under his eyebrow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make up your mind.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD LONG
dialogues.text: The Monarch batter hits a pop fly and the side is retired The Monarch team, including Jackie who goes to shortstop, takes the field. The infielders snap up ground balls thro by first base and we get our first glimpse of Jackie in a as a fielder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various shots of Jackie in action as a shortstop; picking a ground ball and shooting it to first, covering second a throwing to first for a double play, backing up the third baseman on a hot grounder and recovering when the latter  boots one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of ciphers show three innings have been played. the fourth inning slot the figure "1" appears for each te and then further ciphers appear up to the beginning of th ninth inning.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD LONG
dialogues.text: The Monarchs come running in, including Jackie who goes t the bat rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He selects a bat and heads for the plate.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: Jackie first takes a strike, then cuts at the next pitch lines a double into the field. The crowd yells.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD
dialogues.text: As Jackie runs, then slides into second just in time to b the pitch from the outfield. He gets up and dusts himself off as the second baseman, ball in hand, grins at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About time you started hitting, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie grins and the second baseman returns the ball to t pitcher. As he throws, Jackie suddenly lights out for thi and catches the pitcher flatfooted, not expecting such a  daring play. The crowd roars as Jackie slides safely into third.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: Looking disgusted with himself.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE ON THIRD
dialogues.text: Grinning to himself. He obviously loves the sport and enj a spectacular play. He takes a long lead, teasing the pit

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD
dialogues.text: The next batter flies to the infield and Jackie gets back base in time. The shortstop holds the ball for a moment,  then satisfied that Jackie is holding the bag, tosses to pitcher. The moment the ball leaves his hand, Jackie has  started for home. By the time the pitcher catches the bal and relays it to the catcher, Jackie is sliding in safe a home plate. The crowd roars approval of his daring base- running.

dialogues.speaker: AT DUGOUT
dialogues.text: As Jackie returns. Several players grin and ad lib their  approval of the way he has handled himself. As the game  continues, one of the players, Slim, moves close to Jacki and starts a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good going. You ought to sleep well  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I generally sleep pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a bus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) That's right. I forgot we travel by  bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make four hundred mile jumps between  games. Only chance we ever get to  hit a bed is in a two or three game  series.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't de luxe, brother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is designed to show the nomadic life of these  ballplayers. A. Players piling into their own bus at night. B. Players inside bus, half asleep as they travel. C. Shots of game, including Jackie getting a hit. D. Bus traveling again. E. Players dressing on bus, getting into their uniforms. F. Players emerging from bus at ballpark, going right ont field as if they've delayed game by late arrival. G. Inside bus again; night, players asleep, some still in uniform. H. Game in progress. Jackie in good fielding play. I. Shot of fans showing their appreciation of game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monarch bus drives down highway, toward camera, which PULLS BACK and PANS as it disappears down highway, L. to

dialogues.speaker: MONARCH BUS
dialogues.text: As it drives past. Through the windows we get a glimpse o the players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dim illumination we can see the players, a few asl most sprawled out and listening to a major league night g broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slim has a portable radio on his lap. Jackie is in seat b him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's two and two on Greenberg as  Feller winds up... and it's ball  three...

dialogues.speaker: HIGH-PITCHED WAIL FROM REAR OF BUS
dialogues.text: Shut off that radio! I want to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, Leander! That's Hank Greenberg  at bat. (to Jackie) That Leander! He sleeps all day out  in right field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if it's Duke Ellington!  I want to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to radio) Come on, Hank. Wait it out... 'less  it's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the windup again... and  Greenberg SWINGS at a high one and  he's out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a general murmur of disgust from all in the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (provoked) What he bite on that for? (snapping off radio) Ah-h... that's the game!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a lull as everyone settles back with closed eyes Then the plaintive voice of Leander is heard again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey-y-y!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) What you want now, Leander? I turned  the radio off. Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't sleepy no more. I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several players open up their eyes and consider this. The look at each other and seem to indicate Leander has somet

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: The bus driver looks back and then at the manager who occ a front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry? Why you... (on second thought) Hungry... (looking back at Jackie) How about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie compresses his lips and nods as if it isn't a bad  idea at all. Almost immediately other players pick up  Leander's word and we hear them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) Yeah... hungry. I can eat. About  time... gotta get out of here anyway.  I'm for it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks manager who nods in agreement. Driver nods back and peers ahead.

dialogues.speaker: WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: We see a forlorn-looking combination filling station and  lunch room, with several cars parked around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over shoulder) Don't look too bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the players, full of good humor, move around in their  seats, trying to see the lunch room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the bus pulls in and to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: IN BUS
dialogues.text: The players, Jackie included, peering through the bus win studying the almost deserted roadside cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at them all) Whose turn? Let's not waste time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players look at each other and finally Slim gets to h feet. He combs his hair and brushes at his clothes, tryin to look as presentable as possible. The others watch him he leaves the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slim starts toward the cafe. He hesitates at the door for moment, then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plain eating spot with one long counter, usual coffee u and wall aperture through which the chef can be seen in t kitchen. Three male patrons are seated together halfway d from the door, and the counterman, about thirty, is leani against the wall talking to them as Slim enters. The four look towards Slim without any welcome and wait till he  approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Sixteen of us... in the bus outside.  How's chances of getting a late  dinner?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTERMAN
dialogues.text: The patrons look to the counterman to see what his reply  will be. He notes their stare and then folds his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all alone here. Afraid I couldn't  handle you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three patrons now swing their stare on Slim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems not surprised and is ready with his next questio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about sandwiches? Could you have  the chef make some up for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems to be considering this but before he can answer offstage voice is heard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chef, a rugged, elderly fellow is looking through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make you about sixteen beefs, sixteen  ham and eggs. That be all right?

dialogues.speaker: CHEF
dialogues.text: Slim walks to chef as he replies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swell. Some fried potatoes on the  side, chef?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappearing) Yup. (o.s.) Take about twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The counterman walks into scene and stoops under counter get a roll of paper containers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit sulky) Coffee for everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... but don't pour it until the  sandwiches are ready, please... so  the coffee will be hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just getting it ready, Bud. Just  getting it ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates outside with his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suppose we could wash up a bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The counterman sneaks a quick look towards window but the chef is apparently too busy to hear this. He turns back t Slim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. It's out of order.

dialogues.speaker: SLIM MEDIUM
dialogues.text: His face is expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Thanks. Then we'll go up the  road and be back in fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to leave a deposit on the  sandwiches in that case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching into pocket) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slim leaves lunch room and walks slowly to bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting towards front entrance as Slim climbs aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're feeding us. That's all. I  told them we're goin' up the line a  bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without another word the driver starts the motor up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus starts up the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the bus coming to a stop alongside a wooded sectio The door opens and the players straggle out. One by one t disappear from sight as they walk into the woods and bush as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus speeding along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now everyone but the driver is asleep, stretched out in t various and often grotesque postures typical of bus slumb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any sort of corridor in which Rae, in hospital uniform, m another colored nurse. Rae carries medical tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, Rae. I read about your  Jackie last night. He's been going  great for months. He write you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He's doing well. Except he  doesn't like the traveling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell him to give it up and  come back here and get a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with slight smile) I sure feel like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the time to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking head) I'll wait. Waited this long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile and pass on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOWARD BOX OFFICE. A sign visible: "MONARCHS vs. CHICAGO"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fair-sized crowd, players warming up on the field, but game hasn't started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several players stand near the dugout, throwing balls bac and forth. Taking it easy as they warm up. Since most of  them are watching those players on the field, we realize  that the Chicago players are those practicing; the Monarc are waiting for their turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Slim enter the dugout from clubroom runway and notice Bill Piedmont, a pitcher, sitting alone, somewhat  disconsolately. Jackie and Slim settle down on each side Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you? Didn't  you pitch and win yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. You were hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... but there's no future to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'ya mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jackie) How much does a twenty game win  pitcher get paid in the major league?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Thirty thousand up,  maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. And I've won thirty so  far... and I'll get more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you ain't getting any thirty  thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at Slim) Funny boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think you could do as well in the  majors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not any thirty or more. But I'd  sure come close to twenty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) And maybe be able to save a few  dollars for when my arm goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off. Slim watches him and turns to Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right. We're all in the same  boat. Get enough to get by -- but  nothing to put by.

dialogues.speaker: SLIM
dialogues.text: Slim gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't finish but walks out on field leaving Jackie a Jackie sits thinking and we can hear Slim's words echoing his mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (echo box) ...enough to get by -- but nothing  to put by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone calls Jackie and he snaps out of his reverie and  runs onto field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Centering on Jackie at shortstop as play begins. We HEAR crack of a bat and Jackie shoots over to his left to make pickup and throw out to first. It is a neat, fast play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie stepping up to bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see him talking into his mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie Robinson up again. He got a  hit once and walked once. Let's see  what he does now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball flashes by Jackie, low. He makes no move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball one. Too low.

dialogues.speaker: PLATE
dialogues.text: Jackie waggling his bat, drawing it back... but failing t swing as the ball comes by low again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is plainly nettled as he receives ball, gets catcher's sign, and winds up.

dialogues.speaker: PLATE MEDIUM
dialogues.text: From behind catcher. We see Jackie poised to hit, the bal coming... and Jackie merely lifts his elbows to let ball  come through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is not biting. They've got  the wrong man. It's ball three now  and the pitcher's on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wipes sweat from brow. Winds up and --

dialogues.speaker: PLATE MEDIUM
dialogues.text: The ball comes by and without waiting for the umpire's ca Jackie tosses his bat aside and makes for first.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Laughing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball four and Jackie walks again.  He's got eyes, that boy.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD FULL
dialogues.text: With the first baseman in the act of tossing the ball bac to the pitcher -- the ball still in mid-air -- Jackie is on a dash to second. The pitcher is rattled, fumbles  momentarily, and then gets off a high throw. Jackie is sa on a long, hooked slide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monarch players are tumbling into the dugout from the fie ad libbing about winning a tough game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Jackie loping along towards dugout. Suddenly his n is called and he looks towards the boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Robinson! Can I see you a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie pauses, then veers toward the box seats.

dialogues.speaker: BOX SEAT MEDIUM
dialogues.text: Sukeforth is standing as Jackie enters the scene. Sukefor extends his hand and Jackie takes it... wondering and per a little suspicious that he may be dealing with a crank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Clyde Sukeforth. I'm with  Branch Rickey... of the Brooklyn  Dodgers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie neither changes expression nor acknowledges this i any way. Sukeforth climbs out of box onto field and takes Jackie's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll walk up to the dressing room  with you. Talk to you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start off, Jackie still wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stopping outside the dressing room door, Sukeforth begins talking again. Several Monarch players, including Slim, w by and look at them curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch Rickey wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, I don't know. Can you leave  for Brooklyn tonight with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is taken aback by this, then, after studying Sukef he suddenly nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) Great! I'm at the Palmer House. I'll  arrange for our railroad tickets and  suppose you phone me at the Palmer  at seven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do that, Mr. Sukeforth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands and Sukeforth leaves. Jackie stands look after him a moment, his head shaking in wonder. Then he e dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie reaches his locker and starts pulling his shirt of Slim enters scene accompanied by Bill, the pitcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that white man, Jackie? A  friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Said he was a scout for the  Brooklyn Dodgers. Said Branch Rickey  wants to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nudging Bill) S'matter? You owe Rickey some money  or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... what does Mr. Rickey want to  see you about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) He didn't say. Just wants to see me.  Maybe to see if I've got two heads  or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's getting the train tickets and  I'm to phone him at seven at his  hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better hurry up and pack. We'll miss  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) You don't think I'm crazy, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slim and Bill join in the laughter and Bill lets his hand fall on Jackie's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find a lot of these cranks  showing up. I don't know what makes  'em do it. Last year I was signed to  pitch for the Giants, Senators and  Cincinnati.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But none of us have ever been signed  for Brooklyn yet. That's a new one.  You ought to take Bill and me out  and show us a good time on the  strength of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the strength of that I'm going to  have dinner and go home to bed. It's  been four days since we had a bed to  sleep in and I'm going to get a  nightful of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got something there...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He is in bed, sound asleep, when a knock is heard at the  door. Jackie rolls over a bit, paying no attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he lifts his head sleepily when the knocking continues louder this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is silence for a moment, then a dry, angry voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robinson? Clyde Sukeforth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He appears stunned, is completely motionless for a moment then snaps on the bedside lamp. The room is illuminated f the first time and we see that it is a cheap one, poorly  furnished. On the dresser is a framed picture of Rae.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fully awake) Just a second!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets out of bed, in his pajamas, and hurries to open t door. From his expression he still isn't sure what to exp

dialogues.speaker: AT DOOR
dialogues.text: As Jackie opens it and an annoyed-looking Sukeforth enter They stare at each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) What are you trying to pull, Robinson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves into the room, angrily continuing to berate Jack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playing hard to get or something...?  Or just trying to make a fool out of  me? Acting like a smart guy... making  me miss my train... (disgusted) I should have taken it and not come  here...

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING JACKIE
dialogues.text: He is growing indignant at this treatment from a man he i not sure of. He controls his temper, but nevertheless mak himself plain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Mr. Sukeforth -- if  that's your name... I don't know you  and you don't know me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sukeforth looks at him sharply. Jackie hesitates, then  continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If Mr. Rickey did send you to see  me, then I've made a big mistake --  and I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sukeforth doesn't understand for a moment. Then, angrily, reaches into his pocket, brings out his wallet and gives  Jackie a card.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jackie looks up from the card, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still hard to believe... A lot  of fellows come to the game and...  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting Jackie's  reasoning) Oh... You thought I was giving you  the business! I should have thought  of that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie relaxes a bit and waits for Sukeforth to continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) When Mr. Rickey told me to come out  here and talk to you, I didn't think  I was hearing right myself... but  here I am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around the room, then back to Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you said you don't know why he  wants to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no longer angry) I don't... (thoughtfully) Unless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urging him on) After all, there's no chance for me  in major league baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sukeforth nods in agreement --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing I can think of... and  I've got no right to suggest it...  just between us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's talk about an all-Negro  football team being started by Mr.  Rickey... the Brown Dodgers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... so that's it. Football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. But he wants to see  you and he's paying your fare...  both ways if you come back... What  do you say... yes or no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks around the room, plainly at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll just have to make up your  mind, quick. I can't tell you any  more. I don't know any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Let's pack. We leave in an  hour.

dialogues.speaker: EBBETTS FIELD
dialogues.text: A game is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Sukeforth round a corner and walk down the hal toward camera. CAMERA PULLS BACK and PANS to a doorway on which is printed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch Rickey, President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA HOLDS as Jackie and Sukeforth walk up to the door. Sukeforth opens it without knocking and leads Jackie insi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attractive secretary sits at a desk. Two doors lead in adjoining offices. On the walls are signed, framed photog of some of the old and new Dodgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Sukeforth... Mr. Rickey  is expecting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sukeforth leads the way to a door marked "MR. RICKEY." He opens it and motions Jackie to step in first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
