dialogues.text: On Rickey, as he looks up towards camera from his desk in good-sized, well-furnished office, decorated with additio pictures of baseball notables -- officials as well as pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartily) Hello, Clyde! Got your man, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up, warm of face and manner, but we can tell fr the look in his eyes that he is making a quick and keen s of Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Jackie. I'm very glad to  see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sukeforth and Jackie come up to desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mr. Rickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, this is Jackie Robinson... and  it looked for a while as if I wasn't  going to get him here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jackie) Sit down, won't you? (to Sukeforth) Oh, no? (to Jackie) How come? Don't like Brooklyn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he takes a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got nothing against Brooklyn.  But... uh... on the Monarchs we get  all kinds of men who show up and  talk big about signing us up for  this and that. It's a kind of a gag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure! Sure! Sure! But didn't  Clyde show you his credentials?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... we got together finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the main thing... And  now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wondering, naturally, why I  sent for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than wondering, Mr. Rickey. I'm  most curious. Although... I sort of  figured it out for myself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit surprised) You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I know you're starting an all- colored football team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Yes! Yes! We are thinking about  that. But... that's not what I want  you for. (quietly; after pause) Jackie, I want you for baseball.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Jackie is bewildered. He looks towards Sukeforth as if fo help in understanding but Sukeforth's expression is just puzzled. Then Jackie turns back and his face hardens a bi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that as if you were talking  about organized baseball, Mr. Rickey.  But I'm a Negro. There are none of  us in big league ball. I don't  understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I should want to put a Negro  into baseball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) I'm going to tell you... (to Sukeforth) And you, Clyde. (looking off) Because I am going to have to tell  many people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Sukeforth consult each other with another glan as Rickey falls silent a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaning forward to Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been looking for someone like  you -- an intelligent, educated,  good Negro ballplayer -- for some  time. I needed a man whose character  was well regarded and whose background  was unblemished. As far as we can  find out, you are such a man. You  might as well know now... we've done  a lot of checking up on you. I can  tell you your life story from Georgia  to where you are sitting now. It may  be that you will be the first Negro  in organized baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is flabbergasted and, at the same time, beginning to f an excitement which he cannot well hide. But he is also  puzzled, and his hand goes to his chest, indicating himse as he manages to get out one word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rickey stands up and shoots a finger out at Jackie as guessing what is on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you? Let's get this straight so  we can all understand it. It's too  important for anyone to have a false  impression. People are going to shoot  at us... we must know where we stand.  I didn't call you here because I  want to do something for you, or for  your race, or for the Brooklyn Ball  Club. I want to do something for all  of us... All of us Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey turns and gazes out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The park is crowded with fans. (The Brooklyn Ball Club of are not near Ebbetts Field; they are in downtown Brooklyn But the liberty we take is not offensive and should not b objectionable to anyone.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...For years I have seen and watched  Americans together in the grandstands  and bleachers of our country's ball  parks... Negroes, whites of all  nationalities...

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL CROWDS
dialogues.text: Selected to illustrate Rickey's continued speech. (Great  care should be taken here as the proper scenes can lend  pointed and heartwarming emphasis to this important, key  scene. We see Negroes and Whites laughing together, growi tense together, gulping with relief as some emergency is  met. We may have a group CLOSEUP which might include (thi may have to be staged) an American executive type, a Negr and a Jew, suddenly all filled with heartbreak or dismay a hometown hero has apparently struck out, or some other break has ensued. In no case need we show what they are  watching. The faces of the crowds can express the typical emotional situations that come up in any game.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Italians, Irish, Swedes, Jews,  Germans, Chinese, Russians, Japanese,  Czechs... and I have marveled at  their fellowship, their cheers,  laughter, disappointments, enthusiasm,  all as one... and all made so by the  magic of a sport they all loved and  appreciated equally. And I couldn't  help ask myself a question... a long  time ago... and hundreds of times  since -- If Americans can find such  a common meeting ground in a game...  the game of baseball... If they can  play together like this... why can't  they live together like this... in  the game of life?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE MED.
dialogues.text: Over heads of Jackie and Sukeforth towards Rickey still  looking out of window. He turns back and finishes quietly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... I know they can... and maybe  baseball can show the way... because  baseball is wholly and peculiarly  American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is looking at Rickey with new eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I called you here, Jackie.  Do you want to get in on it? Because  it starts with you!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Sukeforth looks to see what Jackie's answer will be, and  Jackie begins nodding slowly, and replies, not as if he i talking to Rickey, but as if he is asking questions of  himself... because this is serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm strong enough. If I should be  the one on whom this all depends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Rickey remains silent --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can try. For all I've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) That should be enough. But I want  you to know exactly what you are  getting into. I'll do my part. You  mustn't let me, or all of us, down.  Jackie, we can't start you with  Brooklyn. It wouldn't be fair to  both of us. We don't know if you're  major league or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods. He agrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll let you try out for Montreal,  one of our farm teams, and later  hope you make Brooklyn. But aside  from that, if and when we announce  you for even Montreal... do you know  what's going to happen? The papers?  People? Other players? Other clubs?  The reaction in the south?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if we get over that and you  actually start with Montreal -- Will  you stand what you're going to have  to go through? The razzing... the  cruel, unfair razzing that every  player gets, and the special razzing,  the special name-calling you're going  to get. Can you stand it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Because... (face grim) You're not going to be able to fight  back... no matter what the offense. (emphasis) ...No matter what the offense! Do  you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Rickey and Sukeforth wait for Jackie's reply. Finall it comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you use a ballplayer who hasn't  the spirit... to fight back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a poser. He rubs his face, his chin, and practically his entire head. Eventually he finds an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what's going to make your job  so tough. No! I want a fighter every  time. I want a man in there for  everything he's got! But... you'll  have to take it... not fight back...  and yet, do it so that somehow it's  no discredit to you... so that somehow  the crowd will sense it's not  cowardice that is stopping you but  something deeper. If, and when, you  can put that over... your troubles  are over. No player will bother you,  no man will unfairly attack you by  name or epithet, when you have  established that with the baseball  public. Because the very core of  Americans is fair play... once they  have felt the true situation involved.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY
dialogues.text: Rickey stands up. Jackie follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, I know from your background  that you've been spiked and beaned  in baseball, you've been clipped and  two-way tackled in football, you've  been banged around on the street.  That's what you face now. And you  don't dare yell copper... or fight  back. You don't dare because more  than you... much more than just you...  hangs in the balance. (extending his hand) Take a day to think it over. And  think it over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake. In the background, Sukeforth enters the scene looking a little dazed at what has happened, in fact, blo off steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Robinson at table knitting as Mack enters in his str cleaning uniform, carrying lunch pail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going, Mom. See you in the  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone rings and Mack goes to it. Mrs. Robinson  watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello... Yes, yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the jangle of heavy coins coming from the receive as Mack turns to his mother in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Jackie, Mom. He's calling from  New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also surprised, and a bit perturbed, she gets up and join Mack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York? What's he doin' there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello... Yeah, Jackie, it's me, Mack.  What are you...? Huh?... The  Dodgers?... The Dodgers!... Yeah...  Yeah... Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Robinson stands quietly waiting, but we can tell she dying to know what it is all about. But Mack is listening Then he finally talks again to Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she's right here, Jackie. Just  a minute, I'll tell her. (turning to mother) Listen, Mom. Jackie's got a chance  to try out for Montreal -- baseball --  and maybe go with the Brooklyn  baseball team afterwards. He'll be  the first Negro in real baseball.  But he has to promise that no matter  what kind of trouble happens -- and  there'll be trouble --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) Will he get hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, not actually... but it could be  nasty... you know. But he's got to  promise not to fight back no matter  what happens to him and he don't  know if he can trust himself to take  it. Feels he'll feel like only half  a man. And if things go wrong on his  account it might be the end of Negroes  in baseball. He doesn't know what to  do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Robinson reaches for the phone but Mack holds it awa and seems surprised at what appears to be a quick decisio on her part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have the phone, Mack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives it to her. She clears her throat and then begins

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie talking into a pay station phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mom! Mack tell you? What do  you think, Mom...? (surprised) What? What? (laughing) Yeah... I feel all right. Yeah, I'm  sure. I feel swell... But what  about...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't advise you, son. You have  to talk to somebody with better  judgment. Somebody in New York you  can sit down with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't know anybody in New  York...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you do, son. In Harlem there  are churches and good men at the  head of them. Find one. Tell him.  And listen. It means as much to him  as it does to you and all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking) Yeah... maybe you're right, Mom.  That does sound good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and take good care of yourself  and let us know... What?... No, we  won't tell anyone until you let us  know... Yes, just Rae. Good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up and turns from phone to Mack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) That was good, Mom. How'd you happen  to think he could go to some church  and talk to a minister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down and takes up her knitting again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needed help and it just naturally  came to me he could go to church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and an elderly minister are seated, both silent,  serious and thoughtful. Jackie seems to be waiting for an opinion from the minister. The latter finally stands up a Jackie follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) I understand. It's quite a problem. (changing tone) Do you have time for a little walk,  Mr. Robinson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) A walk? Well... surely, if you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching for hat) Let's take one.

dialogues.speaker: HARLEM
dialogues.text: This scene, which is one of the most important in the pic will depend almost entirely on footage available, editori selection of scenes, and technical handling. We see Harle at night and get the feeling of humanity so congested, an sometimes so suppressed, that it overruns its boundaries  both physically and emotionally. Yet there is also the mu and laughter of Harlem, and the spirit of a people not to overcome. Song and violence, rowdy kids and sober elders, church and saloon, and always the streets crowded, the  buildings giving an appearance of being stuffed. Intercut these scenes are the minister and Jackie, so that they ap to be looking on and absorbing what they see. Occasionall the minister will glance at Jackie to make sure he is tak it all in. Occasionally he will explain what is going on. and the dialogue for this is to be written when the prope scenes are selected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and the minister have arrived back at the church a stand there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie nods:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that if you don't make good...  it may hurt us. But... (shrugging) ...we always can take hurt, if there  is the chance to benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means I take the chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) We all take the chance. The Lord has  appointed you one of the rising men  of your race. And we've got to be a  rising people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minister looks at him. Jackie nods. He keeps nodding we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of newspaper headlines -- front page --

dialogues.speaker: DODGERS SIGN NEGRO PLAYER
dialogues.text: Jackie Robinson sent to Montreal Royals

dialogues.speaker: NEGRO BREAKS INTO BIG LEAGUE BALL
dialogues.text: Baseball world in furore! Down in the body of one of the newspaper stories is the  following paragraph:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "In the meanwhile, there has been no comment from Jackie  Robinson, who, having returned to his home in Pasadena, i preparing to marry Miss Rae Isum, a schooldays sweetheart

dialogues.speaker: RADIO STUDIO
dialogues.text: An announcer is standing at a mike, reading from a script holds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Branch Rickey announced that  Jackie Robinson had been signed and  would play for the Montreal farm  club there was plenty of excitement.  Almost everybody had something to  say about it -- and what's more --  they said it!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A. Two men arguing on a street corner. B. Men arguing in bar. C. Man and woman arguing. D. Three Negroes discussing a serious problem. E. Group at exclusive club discussing same heatedly. F. Radio commentator talking into mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...The talk came from high places in  baseball as well -- with many a club  owner declaring that they wouldn't  stand for it. But there it was. What  would they do about it? It is  something we won't know until the  season starts in a few weeks in  Florida...

dialogues.speaker: ROBINSON HOME STEPS
dialogues.text: Jackie and Rae are sitting together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtfully) You're sure you want me to come to  Florida with you? I've never been  south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) I'm sure. I'm very sure. Not afraid,  are you?... because of all this fuss  in the papers? I've never been south  either, since babyhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little. But that's not why I wonder  about coming. I just don't want to  be in your way. You'll be busy with  all that spring training... people  wanting to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing softly) Who'll want to talk to me? They talk  about me... but not to me much. If  you aren't there I'll just be alone  once I'm off the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the way you figure it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Why... Dem's the conditions that  prevail... like Jimmy Durante says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sidelong glance) Well... if dem's the conditions,  I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut as Jackie, pleased, starts to put his arm around h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. Shot of Jackie and Rae getting on plane.

dialogues.speaker: PLANE IN FLIGHT., (STOCK)
dialogues.text: 3. Jackie and Rae getting on train. 4. Train speeding along. (Stock) 5. Stock shot - Florida. Palm trees, stucco buildings, et 6. Shot of Jackie and Rae entering bus. Rae is about to t a seat in middle of bus when Jackie stops her and indicat she is to sit in rear of bus. 7. Rae and Jackie in bus as he points to sign near driver 8. Sign, reading: "Colored must sit in rear."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bus coming to stop, driver opening door and passengers  beginning to exit.

dialogues.speaker: BUS DOOR MEDIUM
dialogues.text: Jackie stepping out and helping Rae down as a well-dresse middle-aged Negro steps up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Robinson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rae) And Mrs. Robinson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Gaines. I am an attorney  in town. A group of us heard you  were due here for spring training.  We thought you might not have made  arrangements for a place to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why... we were going to find a  hotel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no suitable hotel, Mr.  Robinson. That's why we talked it  over. I'd be pleased to have you  stop at my home while you are here  as our guests. Such as it is, it is  the only place available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled, looking at  Rae) That's very kind of you... but...  why... we don't want to impose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. You are a very important  man to us. It will be our pleasure,  I assure you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie studies Gaines a moment and then understands. He  extends his hand and both men shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls up outside a comfortable looking frame house. The three, Gains, Jackie and Rae, get out, the two men  dividing the bags between them, and walk towards house. A they get near the door, it opens and a dignified colored  woman steps out and smiles a welcome. From a distance we the introductions made and the group passes inside.

dialogues.speaker: DODGERS' TRAINING FIELD
dialogues.text: A general view of the training field with about fifty-odd players tossing the ball around.

dialogues.speaker: GAINES' CAR
dialogues.text: We see Jackie and Gaines in car as it comes to stop near  field which forms the b.g. Jackie, carrying small zipper  bag, emerges from car, waves thanks to Gaines, and starts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is buttoning up his uniform and nearly a dozen  reporters, most of them white, are shooting questions at  him. Several have notebooks in their hands and are writin down his answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Think you're good enough to make  the Dodgers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know if I'm good enough to  make the Montreal team -- so I'm not  even thinking about the Dodgers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curiously) What'll you do if a pitcher tries to  bean you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Same as you would. Duck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other reporters grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hope to be a Dodger sometime,  don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously) Sure -- provided I'm good enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the other players? You  think there'll be any trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) He means -- do you expect to get  along with the other guys --- Suppose  something happens -- then what? How'll  it affect you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie doesn't answer for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) That's too tough for me to answer.  All I can say is that I'm going to  do my best -- as a player and on and  off the field... How it'll turn out --  I don't know any more than you do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few start writing this down and now the trainer moves u in front of Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, boys -- but you'll have to  continue this later -- right now  Robinson's due on the field...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reporters understand and several move to follow Jacki as he and the trainer exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie, the trainer, and several reporters come up out it and stand there for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: THEIR ANGLE
dialogues.text: Showing ballplayers, some batting, fielding, throwing bal etc. o.s., we hear the trainer's voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Hopper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the call, a tall, greying man in his fifties, in unifo turns around and walks toward Jackie and others, includin camera.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, TRAINER, REPORTERS
dialogues.text: As Mr. Hopper walks into scene and up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie -- this is Mr. Hopper --  Manager of the Montreal Royals --  Mr. Hopper -- Jackie Robinson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both nod and shake hands. Hopper is a hard man to fi out. His accent is Southern -- his attitude calm and quie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a few minutes for us, Mr.  Hopper...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly -- but let me get Jackie  out there first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts moving toward the field as he speaks and Jackie follows him. Then they both stop and look out toward the  playing field.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THEIR ANGLE
dialogues.text: Almost every player on the field is looking in their  direction, curious about Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER AND JACKIE
dialogues.text: As Hopper moves forward again. Jackie is a bit nervous an we can tell that Hopper knows how he feels, but there are words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they move down the first base line toward a player who tossing a ball with two other men who are standing as a p some distance away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Boys... this is Jackie Robinson. (to Jackie) That's Harker, Billings and Piletti.  Catch with them a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players and Jackie nod. Hopper turns away and Jackie  joins Harker who is the lone player, with Billings and Pi some sixty feet away.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOUR
dialogues.text: We ANGLE SEVERAL SHOTS while the following routine takes  place. Piletti throws the ball to Harker who is alongside Jackie. Harker throws it back to Billings. Billings shoul throw now to Jackie -- instead he also throws to Harker.  They keep this up a while, with Piletti and Billings neve throwing to Jackie, just to Harker, and as it goes on and the white men realize they have committed themselves to t insult, their faces sharpen, the atmosphere becomes a lit tense as indicated by the quick glances they shoot each o and the way they avoid even looking at Jackie. It is his  first crisis, a childish one, perhaps, but nevertheless  serious. He stands quietly, his face betraying nothing, b his eyes just following the ball.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: As he studies their faces, his eyes following the ball in flight. He hopes they might be kidding him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their faces serious. It is not a gag.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Looking out toward other players on field.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: Several players, including Clay Hopper, who has turned ar are watching with interest, paying no attention to their practice.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He is troubled, not knowing what to do, but realizing tha he must do something -- yet nothing that will offend the  three players who are still ignoring him. He studies them again.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE
dialogues.text: CAMERA STUDIES their faces for a brief moment. We even fe that they are sorry they have done what they have, but th don't know how to get out of it without one of them turni "chicken."

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He takes a breath and moves a step closer to Harker.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOUR
dialogues.text: Piletti throws again.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: The ball is again intended for Harker but Jackie leans ov and casually gathers it in in a graceful catch. Before th can be any reaction he has the ball on its way back to  Billings.

dialogues.speaker: BILLINGS
dialogues.text: Billings is so unnerved by the whole incident that he fum the ball and has to walk after it.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Jackie turns after throw to find Harker looking at him al gratefully. Harker nods in commendation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad you did that. I don't know how  the heck we got into it.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOUR
dialogues.text: Billings has recovered ball and is so confused by the who episode that, instead of throwing it back to Harker, who extending a glove up in the air as a sign, he throws it t Jackie instead. Harker watches and looks back at Billings Then he calls out in pretended indignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, great! Now you're leaving me out  of it! Oh, fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them have to laugh now and as we cut away Har is begging Jackie for the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here... let me get a chance to throw  once in a while!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face inscrutable, he turns and studies the faces of t other ballplayers who have been watching the incident. Th too, are smiling. Thoughtfully, he walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see two women seated on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae and Mrs. Gaines are talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure you don't want to walk  into town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Well... not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) All right. (studying Rae) You're not nervous about it, are  you? Afraid down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... to tell you the truth, I  wouldn't be comfortable. I've never  been south and I'm afraid I wouldn't  know how to act. You probably don't  understand but... when one isn't  accustomed to... well, sort of  deferring... or whatever it is down  here... (helplessly) I'm afraid I'm not clear. Perhaps if  you explained. I worry about making  a mistake and getting Jackie into  trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) I understand. Of course I do. But it  really isn't as bad as reported.  Some of what you hear is true... a  lot exaggerated. We live our own  lives... and as long as we live our  own lives we are not bothered. Most  of the white people understand our  position and are helping, bit by  bit, to make things better, easier.  We've got to show respect for all of  them -- whether we respect them or  not. Always say Mister or Mrs. --  never use first names, even if they  ask you to. (she smiles) None of those are hard to do, really.  You do defer, but even that isn't  hard -- once you get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every way. In stores, say, don't try  to get waited on until you're the  only one left -- and give way even  if you're first and they come in  later... Never, of course, try or  expect to mix --- and as long as  they come first in everything --  you'll get along all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae is thoughtful for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me -- why are you living here --  instead of up North...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, I like it  down here. Even so... I like it down  here. If I left... it would be like  running away from home. I couldn't  do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I like it, too. It feels like home...  and yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet it's strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Strange. Almost... mysterious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Haines nods in understanding. The two sit silently a

dialogues.speaker: EFFECT
dialogues.text: We get a synoptic impression of activities: Jackie traini a class being instructed in base sliding, Jackie, Rae, Mr and Mrs. Gaines around a card table at home, and, at the  end, a shot showing a group of white Floridians standing silence, watching Jackie taking part in a scrub game.

dialogues.speaker: GAINES' PORCH
dialogues.text: Jackie emerges and Rae comes as far as screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right home after practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae nods as Jackie waves and starts to run down the walk.

dialogues.speaker: GAINES' HOME FULL
dialogues.text: A car pulls up and Gaines gets out just as Jackie comes d the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is serious as he looks towards Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: GAINES
dialogues.text: As Jackie comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Gaines. I was just on my  way to the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaines puts his hand on Jackie's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this morning, Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this... Uh? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come up on the porch. I had a call  from Mr. Rickey. I'll tell you what  he said.

dialogues.speaker: PORCH MEDIUM
dialogues.text: Rae is still standing. Mr. Gaines offers her a chair, the nods to Jackie to take one, and seats himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town has put a stop to mixed  ball playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after pause) You mean... on account of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks at Rae... then back at Gaines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then... you mean I'm through? Is  that what he said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By no means! Mr. Rickey isn't giving  up that easy. You're to train in  another town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) By myself? I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. With the others. Mr. Rickey's  answer to the town was to decide to  move the whole Brooklyn organization  out of here to another town. Not  far. You'll still stay here with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staggered) And I... I'm the cause of all that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Don't hold yourself cheap, Jackie.  Mr. Rickey thinks that you, and what  you stand for, is worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Training session on. A few dozen players on the field,  catching, throwing, batting, etc. Jackie is playing short

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD FOCUSED ON PITCHER AND BATTER
dialogues.text: A batter misses the first pitch, then connects on the sec and runs for first. Jackie scoops up the ball but makes a very bad throw to first -- and the batter is safe.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Looking disgusted with himself, then flexes his right arm few times as he moves back into position.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY AND TWO REPORTERS
dialogues.text: They are watching practice.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD OVER RICKEY AND REPORTERS
dialogues.text: As they watch batting practice. Another batter hits a gro to Jackie. This time he muffs the ball and it goes into t outfield.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY AND REPORTERS
dialogues.text: The cynical reporter grimaces at Jackie's performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what I've heard, you had a good  ballplayer in Robinson. But from  what I've seen -- you've wasted your  time -- (dryly) and mine, too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other two reporters show nothing. Rickey isn't bother

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to cynic) Could be... but I don't think so... (turns around and  calls o.s., to trainer) Pete -- tell Robinson I want him at  first base...

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDE RICKEY, REPORTERS, TRAINER
dialogues.text: As the trainer nods to Mr. Rickey and trots out on the fi As he leaves, the first reporter turns to Rickey curiousl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ever played first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I know of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Because he's been trying so hard  he's thrown his arm out... it won't  be so hard on him at first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reporters think about this, but the cynic isn't impre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just how bad is his arm, Mr. Rickey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what I've heard, he can't even  comb his own hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you're keeping him out  there...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trainer comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to trainer) How long before his arm...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week will bring it around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey thinks about it, then turns to the reporters, look directly at the cynic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suggest that you catch our first  exhibition game -- two weeks from  today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- Jacksonville...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over scene is title: JACKSONVILLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fans milling around box-office. A few reading sign on box office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The authority for the cancellation is partially covered s that we do not have to blame anybody.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: A few disgruntled fans muttering in disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: AT GATE
dialogues.text: It is padlocked and a policeman stands in front of it. As scene opens, a dozen or so ballplayers, in business or sp clothes instead of uniform, are walking into scene and up gate. Jackie is among them.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: The trainer moves up toward the cop as the players ask hi to open the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) How's about opening up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not today, I'm afraid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players do not know what's wrong. The trainer moves u to the policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bothered) Why not? Whose orders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- there's a statute on the  books that says white and colored  can't compete against each other --  even in sports...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trainer looks as though he's about to explode and so some of his players. Jackie looks upset. The trainer shru helplessly and motions toward the players to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start back and CAMERA PANS them to sidewalk where th start walking o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the 2nd Reporter and the cynic meet the players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to trainer) Pete -- what's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Cancelled -- usual reason...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not bothered) Think you'll ever play a game down  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding his temper) We'll play all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoulders on past the reporters and the players follow him... As they walk o.s. we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA reveals ball park's name:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jersey City vs. Montreal Royals

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few players warming up. A few hundred fans in stands an more entering. Most of the ball players are around the  dugouts, all of them in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch Rickey and Clay Hopper are standing in conference  near the dugout. Players, including Jackie, in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I want you to use him --  trouble or not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Okay. (turning) Hey -- Robinson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie comes up to them from b.g. Waits for them to speak him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie -- I want you to play second  today... (looking at Jackie's  arm) Arm working all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously) Give it all you've got today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, Mr. Rickey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey motions for him to join his teammates and he does Rickey is thoughtful for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to stay for awhile -- just  in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) It'll probably take some time --  after they find out Robinson's in  the game...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk away, talking about the situation.

dialogues.speaker: GAME IN PROGRESS
dialogues.text: Scoreboard reads: 1 to 1 -- 2nd Inning. Fans seem to be  enjoying the game. The batter scores an out and the teams change sides as we HOLD. The Royals are coming to bat. EXT. PLAYERS BENCH DUGOUT IN B.G. A player selects a bat and moves to take up his position the plate as the pitcher and catcher warm up. Hopper moti to Jackie who steps forward and picks out his own bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Anything special?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- use your own judgment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie nods again, swings his bat, and moves up to the "o deck" spot. As he does so, the first batter gets a hit an races toward first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the batter reaches first safely and Jackie moves up in the batter's box.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY
dialogues.text: He is watching game. Two reporters, the cynic included, s with Rickey.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE AT PLATE RICKEY'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: The first pitch is a called strike. The second is a ball. The third is a ball. Fourth a strike. Fifth a ball. Sixth ball and Jackie walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch him... See that stance -- see  how he hugs the plate... He's hard  to pitch to -- he'll walk at least  one for four...

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: At this point we go into a special sequence which must be worked out at time of shooting between Jackie and the  director. It is designed as a demonstration of what makes good ball player as illustrated by Jackie... with Rickey  commenting on him for the benefit of the two reporters. T action is not confined to any one inning but spreads over the entire game in montaged scenes that take in his hitti funning and fielding. It should end up a memorable sequen for all who play or enjoy baseball and believe, usually  wrongly, that they know all its tricks, embracing not onl physical skill but headwork as well. When it is over the  entire audience must have a knowledge and appreciation of what makes Jackie Robinson the player he is... and,  furthermore, a better knowledge of baseball itself.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY
dialogues.text: Hopper enters scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see you alone a moment, Mr.  Rickey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey smells trouble. He makes his excuses to reporters, who also sense something in the air, and walks off with  Hopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've just got word. Police are on  the way. Mixed playing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get him off the field, Clay...  no use making it worse...

dialogues.speaker: TO INCLUDE HOPPER
dialogues.text: He nods at Rickey and heads back toward dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hopper walks up to players' bench. Jackie and the play look up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Jackie -- but you'd better  leave the park for awhile... The old  trouble. See you in the dressing  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie gets up and slowly walks down into the dugout and  towards dressing rooms. The other players are silent, yet we feel, resentful about this unfair situation Jackie has buck constantly.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He starts pulling off his uniform and the trainer walks i scene. Jackie is definitely unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) Same old thing. Same old thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Pete. Thanks for looking at it  my way but I bet you fellows are fed  up with all the trouble I've caused.  All the jumping around, cancelled  games... ruction in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squarely) Yes, it's been a lot of fuss. But  that's the game. We're getting paid  for it. Not our business to squawk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing) It's the game... but I'll never get  to play it, I'm afraid. I've got a  hunch that maybe Mr. Rickey has  enough, too... and maybe I'll be  back with the Kansas City Monarchs  in a few days... if they'll take me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is about to reply when the sound of a door opening m them both turn towards the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: DRESSING ROOM DOOR LONG
dialogues.text: Rickey and Hopper are entering. They walk purposely and R beckons with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete... better go out on the field  and take a look at Hugh's hand. He  caught one on the knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: As Rickey and Hopper enter scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving) Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jackie) And you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Rickey. You going to give  it to me now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give you what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My walking papers. You must be caught  up with all this melodramatic stuff...  police chasing the team all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (winking at Hopper) Yeah. Never had such excitement in  years. (back to Jackie) I'll give it to you. Jackie... you  are now officially a Montreal Royal.  You have made the team. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, who has been sitting a bit dejectedly, straighten up slowly and looks from one to the other. His face is fi more with wonder than anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unbelievingly) You're still with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hopper nods --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking head) And I was ready to give up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems lost in thought, his gaze directed at a far corn of the room, as Rickey gives him a farewell pat on the  shoulder and exits. Jackie doesn't even look up. Then Hop is standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Jackie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waking up) Yes, Mr. Hopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I've got even better news for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brows knitting) Better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you. You can pack up. We head  north tomorrow... for Jersey City  and our first game of the season.

dialogues.speaker: GAINES HOME DINNER TABLE
dialogues.text: With his wife and Jackie and Rae seated before him, Mr. G rises to propose a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is safe to say, Jackie, that this  drink is not the only one to be raised  in your honor tonight. It is safe to  say that hundreds of thousands of  our people are doing the same. You  have opened another door formerly  locked to us by intolerance. It is a  milestone... I speak for a great  many when I say... thank you... thank  you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gaineses and Rae drink, but when Jackie, embarrassed, tries to take his glass, Rae puts her hand on it, laughin and stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not supposed to drink now.  You don't drink, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) I forgot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train roaring through the night.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW
dialogues.text: Stadium on a gala day, pennants streaming, stands packed. (Or any comparable stadium will do.) As we look at it, th legend: "JERSEY CITY, APRIL 14, 1946" appears over the  picture. Then the picture gradually darkens until we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is seated at desk, reading from his notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This was an unusual day in  organized baseball, ladies and  gentlemen. For the first time, a  Negro player was presented to the  public. And for his first time, a  Negro made his appearance in the big  time, his every instinct telling him  the crowd might not be friendly at  all. But whatever the feeling of the  crowd before they saw Jackie Robinson  today... they forgot it. Because he  made them think of one thing... and  one thing only... baseball! And what  baseball! Few will forget what they  saw... I can see it yet...

dialogues.speaker: PLATE JACKIE AT BAT
dialogues.text: He is waggling his bat.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD
dialogues.text: Runners on first and second waiting to go.

dialogues.speaker: THE STANDS
dialogues.text: The fans are silent, watchful.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: He winds up and throws.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He takes a ball.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: Another throw.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Swings and fouls off. Waiting. Another ball. Another ball

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: Winding up.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: A called strike.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: Shows two strikes and three balls.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Crowds tense.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: Checking runners, then winding up and throwing.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Swinging and connecting as a roar comes from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: OUTFIELD
dialogues.text: Outfielder starting to run, then stopping as he realizes  ball will clear fence easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But a lot of players hit home  runs. He gave them more baseball  than that. He gave them real baseball.  When next he came to bat there were  yells for another homerun. Jackie  didn't hit a homerun. He showed the  crowd something brand new... how to  score on a bunt!

dialogues.speaker: PLATE LONG
dialogues.text: ANGLING from third or left field to take in most of infie including home plate and first base. Jackie bunts towards third and beats the throw to first.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND
dialogues.text: Shooting from left field side of second along the line to first base and taking in pitcher. Jackie is taking a long lead off first as pitcher gets ready to throw. With the p he is off for second, running towards us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catcher receives pitch and whips throw to second.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND
dialogues.text: Continuation of former shot showing Jackie going into sli and beating throw to second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Receives ball from second baseman in disgust and turns ar towards plate. Only once, before throwing, does he turn a to eye Jackie, then he starts his windup. The second he g into it there is a roar from the crowd and we can tell fr the frantic look that comes into the pitcher's eyes that knows what is happening -- Jackie must be off again... th time for third! But it is, of course, too late for him to anything but finish his throw.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD BASE LINE
dialogues.text: Jackie racing along.

dialogues.speaker: CATCHER
dialogues.text: Reaching high for a bad throw, then whipping ball.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD BASE
dialogues.text: Jackie sliding in under throw.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: The crowd yelling and laughing at this continued larceny Jackie's part.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: Receiving throw from third baseman and tucking glove unde arm to wipe his brow and glare towards Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD
dialogues.text: Jackie dusting himself off as third baseman looks on cold

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: Ready to throw. He checks Jackie and starts windup.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD
dialogues.text: Shooting to show both Jackie and the pitcher, the latter the b.g. With the downswing of the pitcher's arm, Jackie off and the crowd roars again. But after a half dozen sto Jackie stops suddenly and dashes back to third, just beat a try from the catcher to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD
dialogues.text: Taking in Jackie and the pitcher, the former dancing away from third distractingly and the latter plainly worried b Jackie's tactics and snapping a couple of throws to third an effort to trap him off base. Finally, the pitcher begi his windup and immediately Jackie is off for third. With yell from the crowd the pitcher stops in mid-windup to ma a quick throw to third again. Again Jackie has stopped an is on his way back to third but the umpire there waves hi away and signals that he may go on to home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pitcher's balk. You can score.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD
dialogues.text: The pitcher comes running over to umpire to protest but  realizes after a few words that he plainly made a balk an has no chance. He walks back to mound dejectedly.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Crowd roaring.

dialogues.speaker: DUGOUT
dialogues.text: Jackie tumbling in as pleased teammates slap him on the b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Before that game was over Jackie  had hit safely four times and scored  four times, with the aid of two stolen  bases and two pitcher's balks! Yes,  ladies and gentlemen, that was how  the first day went for the first  Negro in organized baseball. They  probably won't all go that well...  there may still be trouble... But we  have an indication that Jackie  Robinson has what it takes... to  take hold of the public's heart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over which appears legend: "SYRACUSE."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie takes a strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Hey, dare, big boy! What you-all  doin' on a white man's field?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie turns head briefly in direction of ground boxes wh voice, mimicking a thick southern accent, is coming from.

dialogues.speaker: LOWER BOX
dialogues.text: A thick-necked toughie is doing the yelling. He continues in a manner which he calculates will tickle those around  him. Next to him is another man who bends over to fumble  with something at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get your carcass out'a there  before you get rode out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other man comes up with a black cat around whose neck length of strong twine has been attached. The man throws cat onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears a yell of laughter from some of the crowd and lo around.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE LONG
dialogues.text: Shooting from behind him towards box where cat is being m to run back and forth along box, and where Thick-Neck is  yelling again, ostensibly about the cat, but while lookin at Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that black --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A laugh from his companion drowns out the next word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- off the field. Get him off the  field!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see that a number of fans are not impressed with t type of humor.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER LONG
dialogues.text: Smiling at the byplay, he winds up just as Jackie turns  towards him.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE LONG
dialogues.text: We can see the cat business going on in the b.g. as Jacki pulls his bat back, swings and connects.

dialogues.speaker: OUTFIELD LONG
dialogues.text: As ball falls safe for a texas leaguer, Jackie going on t second.

dialogues.speaker: GROUND BOX
dialogues.text: Attendant has appeared and makes the two men lift the cat back with them in the box.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD
dialogues.text: Shooting from center field and taking in Jackie on second and the next man at bat. We see the pitcher throw and the batter hitting a long single on which Jackie easily goes  around third to home. As Jackie turns to go back to the  visiting team's dugout his path brings him near the groun box seat where the cat has been sat on the box rail.

dialogues.speaker: GROUND BOX
dialogues.text: As Jackie passes and the man holding the cat holds it up Jackie and jeers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a brother of yours, Jackie.  Why don't you take him along? He  wants to get into baseball, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie veers suddenly towards box and man falls back in a But Jackie makes no menacing motion. Instead he picks up cat and starts unloosening the twine as he walks away.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE TRUCKING
dialogues.text: We walk with Jackie as he gets the twine loose, holds the cat close and pets him comfortingly.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: The fans watching in silence as Jackie, walking with cat  below, steps into dugout. Suddenly someone applauds. It i taken up and soon the entire park is echoing with the  handclapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sitting in the shadows, his hand still fondly pett the cat.

dialogues.speaker: EFFECT
dialogues.text: Our radio commentator again double-exposed against a  background which includes a series of quick shots showing Jackie playing, crowds cheering, an occasional jeering fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...With the baseball season almost  over, Jackie Robinson has proved  himself one of the standout players  in the International League. In his  home town, Montreal, he is a hero.  To the great majority of fans in  other International League towns, he  is also a favorite. There's no doubt  of it. Jackie has made good here...  but the biggest hurdle is ahead of  him... the major league. The  opposition is strengthening. There  are going to be fireworks!

dialogues.speaker: MONTREAL
dialogues.text: There are stock shots available of the riotous scenes whe the Montreal Royals won the International League pennant 1946 and the crowd went wild over Jackie, riding him arou on their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTREAL ROYALS WIN INTERNATIONAL PENNANT! Jackie Robinson Leads League in Hitting!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Continuation of stock shots of Montreal celebration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fan throwing confetti, supposedly on the crowd below.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The confetti turns into snow and we see empty, snow-cover ball park.

dialogues.speaker: GAINES HOME LONG
dialogues.text: Gaines and his wife emerge on porch just as postman comes the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaines accepts letter from postman who exits after they  exchange greetings. He opens letter and begins to read wh Mrs. Gaines turns to go back into house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Clara. This is from  Jackie Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Is he coming back here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's why he writes. He's on  his way to Cuba. That's where Brooklyn  and Montreal will train this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Does he think he can go with Brooklyn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) He says all he has to do is beat two  hundred other men trying for the  team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (face falling) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. He has to show he  is able. The important thing is... (significantly) ...he has nothing else against him.  He, and all of us, have come that  far, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He folds letter slowly and thoughtfully as she pats his a understandingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HAVANA
dialogues.text: A legend reads: "HAVANA, CUBA."

dialogues.speaker: HAVANA STADIUM
dialogues.text: The Montreal team is working out in the field preparatory playing a game, with the ball being whipped out around th infield. Jackie is playing second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just close enough so we can read the insignia on the unif of the players and know that it is the Brooklyn team whic will oppose Montreal.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD FULL
dialogues.text: Shooting from second towards home plate we see a trainer his hands to his mouth as if to yell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Robinson! Mr. Rickey wants to see  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie waves acknowledgement and then starts trotting in.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE MEDIUM
dialogues.text: Rickey is standing alone, holding a first baseman's glove As Jackie enters scene Rickey nods and flips the glove to Jackie who catches it but looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me? This is a first baseman's  glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. I want you to use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it. Not play second, you  mean? Mr. Rickey, I don't like first  base. I'm not a first baseman. I did  well at second last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, your team begins a seven  game practice series against Brooklyn  today. I want you to play first. I  want you to play like you've never  played before. Last year at Montreal  doesn't mean a thing. This is it.  This is where you decide whether  Brooklyn wants you... and by Brooklyn  I don't mean me -- I mean the Brooklyn  players. I want you to run them  ragged, on the bases, in the field,  at bat. Run wild. Steal their pants  off. They know they are definitely  weak at first. They want to win the  pennant. Make them wonder if their  chances wouldn't be better if they  had you. If they wonder loud enough...  I'll get you for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie still has a fielder's glove on his hand. Slowly he shakes it off and puts the first baseman's glove on inste He seems to have forgotten that Rickey is there. He pound his fist into the pocket of the glove thoughtfully and th without another word, still deeply preoccupied apparently walks off. Rickey's gaze follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie awkwardly scrambling for one in the dirt at first barely recovering to make the out. Jackie hitting. Jackie racing in for a bunt, turning to find no one at first, an then racing the runner to the bag for the out. After whic he mops his brow wearily. Jackie running the bases, steal into a base, beating a pitcher's throw to trap him, teasi the pitcher, teasing again, then away on a run. Jackie  hitting. Jackie hitting again. Jackie walking. And again hitting as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde Sukeforth is at a desk working away with a pencil a some figuring. Nearby stands Rickey waiting. Clyde makes final notation, tosses the pencil away and shakes his hea unbelievingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen anything like it  before. His fielding was only fair,  as you know. He was new to first  base. But, at bat!... For the seven- game series Jackie stole seven bases  and hit .625!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Pretty good. Pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde is amazed at this conservatism, and his face is a s as Rickey nods and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie at a small desk, writing. His voice is heard telli us some of the words he is putting down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Training is over, Rae. I've had  no word yet. We fly to New York  tomorrow to play exhibition games  against Brooklyn on April 9th and  10th. The tenth is the last day before  the official season begins so if I  don't hear by then... I know I'm  cooked. They say that some of the  Dodgers didn't want me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simply two wicker chairs against a palm trunk or tropical plant of any suitable type for a background. Rickey and H are seated and talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) It's a tough problem. Most of the  players see his value, a few don't.  That still leaves a Dodger team  divided against itself. I don't want  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... unless you could take a chance  that they would all come around when  they see that Jackie is helping them  towards a common cause -- the pennant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking) I don't know... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is at the mike calling the game as he sees it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here is Jackie Robinson up  again in the last exhibition game  before the start of the official  National League season. Jackie has  had two chances to show whether Rickey  is wrong in not signing him for  Brooklyn -- and failed to get a hit  both times. Let's see what he does  now with a man on first to bring in.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD LONG
dialogues.text: Showing Jackie at plate and another Montreal player on fi

dialogues.speaker: PLATE
dialogues.text: Jackie waggling his bat, apparently determined to come  through.

dialogues.speaker: MONTREAL DUGOUT
dialogues.text: They are watching Jackie keenly when another player jumps into the dugout excitedly and says something to some of t players. The others hear his words and turn to him in gre interest, forgetting about Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: Winding up and throwing.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Swinging and hitting.

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD
dialogues.text: Angling to show that Jackie has hit into an easy double p so easy that he stops running about two-thirds of the way first and turns to lope back to the Montreal dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't so hot. An easy double  play. It's hard to believe after the  sensational reports of Jackie's  playing in Cuba. Well, everybody has  a bad day and I imagine he is feeling  pretty blue now as he runs towards  his dugout... (puzzled) No! He isn't sad at all... He's  smiling. (excitedly) Wait a moment! Something's going on  at the Montreal dugout. All his  teammates are running out to greet  him as they would a hero! What in...

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD
dialogues.text: Shooting towards dugout, we see the Montrealers running o to Jackie, grabbing his hand, pounding him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYERS
dialogues.text: Several of them clustered around Jackie are all talking a once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad libbing) You've made it, Jackie! The  announcement just came out! You're a  Dodger, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is nodding, smiling, yet still incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They've had to announce it to the  crowd here, ladies and gentlemen.  What we heard from Cuba was right.  Jackie Robinson was good enough to  be signed by Brooklyn. He's a Dodger --  finally!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE AND CLAY HOPP
dialogues.text: They are standing together at one end of the room, Jackie listening to Hopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) ...and I mean it when I say I'm glad  you're going with the Dodgers... (wryly) ...Even though I'd like to keep you  with the Royals...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie knows that Hopper means it and it affects him, as  they shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Mr. Hopper -- I really appreciate  all the help you've given me... And  I mean it, too, when I say that last  year in Montreal was the happiest  year I've ever had... Rae and I'd  just as soon live there the rest of  our lives...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is leaning over Rickey's desk and signing his cont while Rickey looks on. When Jackie finishes, Rickey puts his hand and they shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My congratulations, Jackie. The going  is still going to be tough. But I  can trust you now to take what comes  and not lose your head until you win  the National League players over  like you did in the International  League.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can trust me, Mr. Rickey. I can't  afford to fail. My career is no longer  a personal one, as you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against a background which illustrates the tough time Jac had in the National League his first season -- getting sp ducking baseballs, being given the "hip" in his baserunni we see newspaper stories headed variously: ROBINSON SPIKED AGAIN YESTERDAY

dialogues.speaker: PLAYERS DENY ANTI-ROBINSON PLOT, SAY ROUGHNESS ACCIDENTAL
dialogues.text: ROBINSON CALM IN NIGHT GAME FRACAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever the scenes, Jackie is shown as quietly accepting whatever happens and standing clear while his teammates d him. The news stories are dated to show the progression o the summer months during the 1947 season, or else we migh show the calendar months being stripped off one by one. Part of the same effect is the following headline: HOLD JACKIE ROBINSON NIGHT AT EBBETTS FIELD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we insert stock shots showing Jackie out in the fiel receiving the Cadillac car, television set, etc., with hi mother and Rae also present at the ceremonies in his hono

dialogues.speaker: THERE FOLLOWS THE HEADLINE
dialogues.text: ROBINSON WINS "ROOKIE OF THE YEAR" AWARD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We illustrate here with stock newsreel shot of Jackie at  Baseball Writers Award Dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This announcer is possibly Walter Winchell or Drew Pearso or some other national name if proper arrangements can be made (i.e., a Damon Runyon Fund benefit in the case of Wa Winchell, etc.).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, ladies and gentleman, near  the close of the 1949 baseball season,  a great National League player, and  outstanding American citizen, is on  his way to Washington. His name is  Jackie Robinson. He isn't going there  to play ball. But he is going to  talk about how an American patriot  plays ball with the country that  extends him the right to fight for  freedom. He has been asked to discuss  the patriotism of the American  Negro... before the members of the  Un-American Activities Committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We show those scenes of Jackie in which he is beginning t selected excerpts given below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can put me down as an expert on  being a colored American, with thirty  years of experience at it. And just  like any other colored person with  sense enough to look around him and  understand what he sees, I know that  life in these United States can be  mighty tough for people who are a  little different from the majority --  in their skin, color or the way they  worship their God, or the way they  spell their names. I'm not fooled  because I've had a chance open to  very few Negro Americans. It's true  that I've been the laboratory specimen  in a great change in organized  baseball. I'm proud that I've made  good on my assignment to the point  where other colored players will  find it easier to enter the game and  go to the top. But I'm very well  aware that even this limited job  isn't finished. As I see it there  has been a terrific lot of  misunderstanding on this subject of  communism among Negroes in this  country, and it's bound to hurt my  people's cause unless it's cleared  up. I understand that there are some  few Negroes who are members of the  Communist party, and in event of war  with Russia they would probably act  just as any other Communists would.  So would members of other minority  and majority groups... Most Negroes --  and Italians and Irish and Jews and  Swedes and Slavs and other Americans --  would act just as all these groups  did in the last war. They'd do their  best to help their country stay out  of war; if unsuccessful, they'd do  their best to help their country win  the war -- against Russia or any  other enemy that threatened us... I  can't speak for any fifteen million  people any more than any other one  person can, but I know that I've got  too much invested for my wife and  child and myself in the future of  this country, and I and other  Americans of many races and faiths  have too much invested in our  country's welfare, for any of us to  throw it away. I am a religious man.  Therefore, I cherish America where I  am free to worship as I please, a  privilege which some countries do  not give. And I suspect that 999 out  of almost any 1,000 colored Americans  you meet will tell you the same thing.  But that doesn't mean that we're  going to stop fighting race  discrimination in this country until  we've got it licked. It means that  we're going to fight it all the harder  because our stake in the future is  so big. We can win our fight without  the Communists and we don't want  their help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT into speech are scenes of typical Negro life, bo impoverished and comparatively affluent, selected to best illustrate his particular words at the moment. There is a CLOSEUP of Jackie as he reaches his final words. As he sp them we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: EFFECT
dialogues.text: This is the silhouette that began the picture, showing Ja in action. As his silhouette performs across the screen, following titles begin rolling up:
